article_title: Proposed S.F. fee would squeeze hospital construction
article_text:
Proposed S.F. fee would squeeze hospital construction

Photo: Michael Macor, The Chronicle A MUNI streetcar passes by the newly completed condo and retail...

With all the strains placed on the city’s nonprofit hospitals, now is not the time to tack on millions of dollars in additional fees that would prevent them from expanding to meet growing demand. But that would be the net effect of an amendment to the proposed Transportation Sustainability Fee now being considered by a key committee of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By David Serrano Sewell
article_metadata.description: The fee, based on square footage, is tacked on new construction in the city, with the money earmarked for transportation-related projects such as improved pedestrian walkways, bicycle lanes, new buses and maintenance.  Worse, the higher construction costs would prevent the hospitals from responding to the growing demands for services by building new emergency rooms, expanding outpatient clinics or buying new technology for better patient care.  Construction costs already are prohibitive in the city; hospitals in San Francisco spend up to $4 million for each hospital bed added.  [...] a blanket fee on even routine expansions could have a devastating impact on the ability of nonprofit hospitals to meet increasing patient demands.  [...] 2.7 million Californians have been added to the Medi-Cal rolls under the Affordable Care Act, at the same time fewer and fewer primary care doctors are accepting new Medi-Cal patients, thanks to California’s shamefully low reimbursement rates.  Amending the fee legislation as proposed by the Planning Commission would have the unintended consequence of forcing these essential health care providers to stay within their existing building footprint even as patient demand increases.
